title: Judges Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who was the man from Mount Ephraim mentioned in Judges 17:1?
options: Micah
Gideon
Samson
Ehud
questions.correctAnswer: Micah
questions.explanation: Judges 17:1 states that the man of Mount Ephraim was named Micah.

questions.question: How much silver did Micah admit to taking from his mother according to Judges 17:2?
options: Eleven hundred shekels
One hundred shekels
Five hundred shekels
Two thousand shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Eleven hundred shekels
questions.explanation: Judges 17:2 mentions eleven hundred shekels of silver taken by Micah from his mother.

questions.question: What did Micah's mother say she had dedicated the silver for in Judges 17:3?
options: To make a graven image and molten image
To build a house
To buy land
To pay debts
questions.correctAnswer: To make a graven image and molten image
questions.explanation: Judges 17:3 states that the mother had dedicated the silver to make a graven and molten image.

questions.question: How much silver did Micah's mother keep to make the graven and molten images according to Judges 17:4?
options: Two hundred shekels
Five hundred shekels
Eleven hundred shekels
One hundred shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Two hundred shekels
questions.explanation: Judges 17:4 shows that the mother took two hundred shekels to give to the founder for making images.

questions.question: What religious items did Micah have in his house as mentioned in Judges 17:5?
options: An ephod and teraphim
A scroll and lamp
A harp and altar
A sword and shield
questions.correctAnswer: An ephod and teraphim
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 states that Micah had an ephod and teraphim in his house.

questions.question: Who became Micah's priest according to Judges 17:5?
options: One of his sons
A Levite from Judah
A stranger
A prophet
questions.correctAnswer: One of his sons
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 says Micah consecrated one of his sons to be his priest.

questions.question: According to Judges 17:6, what was the state of leadership in Israel during those days?
options: There was no king in Israel
Israel was ruled by Pharaoh
David was king
There was a strong monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: There was no king in Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 states there was no king in Israel at that time.

questions.question: From which town did the young Levite come, as mentioned in Judges 17:7?
options: Bethlehemjudah
Jericho
Nazareth
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Bethlehemjudah
questions.explanation: Judges 17:7 states the young Levite was from Bethlehemjudah.

questions.question: Where did the Levite go to find a place to sojourn according to Judges 17:8?
options: Mount Ephraim
Jerusalem
Samaria
Gilead
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Ephraim
questions.explanation: Judges 17:8 tells that the Levite journeyed to Mount Ephraim to the house of Micah.

questions.question: What did Micah offer the Levite to persuade him to stay according to Judges 17:10?
options: Ten shekels of silver, a suit of apparel, and victuals
Land and livestock
A house and servants
Gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: Ten shekels of silver, a suit of apparel, and victuals
questions.explanation: Judges 17:10 records Micah's offer of ten shekels, clothing, and food to the Levite.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 17:6 says that every man did that which was right in the eyes of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 says every man did that which was right in his own eyes, not necessarily in the eyes of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 17:11, the Levite was like one of Micah's sons.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 17:11 states the young Levite was unto Micah as one of his sons.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 17:9 says the Levite came from Mount Ephraim originally.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 17:9 says the Levite was from Bethlehemjudah, not Mount Ephraim.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Judges 17:13: 'Now know I that the LORD will do me _______, seeing I have a Levite to my priest.'
options: good
harm
justice
peace
questions.correctAnswer: good
questions.explanation: Judges 17:13 states Micah said, 'Now know I that the LORD will do me good,' because he had a Levite as priest.

questions.question: What did Micah do to the Levite after he agreed to stay according to Judges 17:12?
options: Consecrated him as priest
Sent him away
Made him a king
Gave him silver only
questions.correctAnswer: Consecrated him as priest
questions.explanation: Judges 17:12 says Micah consecrated the Levite and he became his priest.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with honesty in their workplace. Based on Judges 17:2-3, what biblical truth would you share about integrity?
options: Confess and restore what was taken to honor God
Keep quiet about wrongdoings to avoid trouble
Claim what belongs to you even if it was stolen
Ignore the sin if it doesn’t affect you directly
questions.correctAnswer: Confess and restore what was taken to honor God
questions.explanation: Judges 17:2-3 shows Micah confessing to his mother that he took the silver and then restoring it, highlighting the importance of honesty and making restitution.

questions.question: How does Judges 17:4 teach about stewardship and generosity in the use of resources?
options: Giving part of resources to create something dedicated to the Lord
Keeping all resources for personal enjoyment
Selling resources for profit without giving to God
Ignoring the resources as they have no value
questions.correctAnswer: Giving part of resources to create something dedicated to the Lord
questions.explanation: Judges 17:4 shows the mother using 200 shekels of silver to commission an image dedicated to the Lord, illustrating responsible stewardship and dedicating resources to God.

questions.question: A believer is confused about spiritual leadership. What warning from Judges 17:5 about church roles and obedience would you share?
options: Spiritual leaders must be properly appointed and consecrated according to God’s Word
Anyone can appoint themselves as a priest without accountability
Spiritual leadership is optional in the life of a believer
Personal preference is the best guide for spiritual roles
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual leaders must be properly appointed and consecrated according to God’s Word
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 shows Micah consecrating his son as priest, a practice not authorized by God, warning about improper leadership and the need for obedience to His Word.

questions.question: How does Judges 17:6 relate to the importance of submitting to God’s authority in daily life?
options: Without a king or God’s law, people do what seems right, leading to disorder
Everyone naturally follows God’s commands without guidance
Authority is unnecessary for moral living
Doing what is right in one’s own eyes always leads to blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Without a king or God’s law, people do what seems right, leading to disorder
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 highlights the lack of central authority causing each to do what seems right, emphasizing the need for submission to God’s established authority for order.

questions.question: A believer is feeling isolated and unsure about serving God. What encouragement does Judges 17:7-8 offer about seeking God’s direction and fellowship?
options: God’s servants may need to journey and seek places to serve faithfully
It is best to stay where comfortable and avoid change
Serving God requires no effort or seeking
Isolation proves God’s rejection
questions.correctAnswer: God’s servants may need to journey and seek places to serve faithfully
questions.explanation: Judges 17:7-8 describes the Levite leaving his city to find a place to serve, encouraging believers to seek God’s guidance and fellowship even if it means change.

questions.question: How does Judges 17:9-10 teach us about hospitality and supporting spiritual leaders?
options: Offering support and provision to those who serve in ministry
Ignoring spiritual leaders’ needs
Demanding service without support
Expecting spiritual leaders to work without help
questions.correctAnswer: Offering support and provision to those who serve in ministry
questions.explanation: Judges 17:9-10 shows Micah inviting the Levite to live with him and providing him with a salary and food, teaching generosity and support for those serving God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in their role in the church. What principle from Judges 17:11-12 can help?
options: Being content and faithful in the role God provides brings blessing
Always seek higher positions regardless of God’s will
Discontentment is expected and unavoidable
Service without joy is meaningless
questions.correctAnswer: Being content and faithful in the role God provides brings blessing
questions.explanation: Judges 17:11-12 shows the Levite content to dwell and serve as priest, highlighting the blessing of faithfulness and contentment in God’s provision.

questions.question: How does Judges 17:13 teach about trusting God’s goodness in our spiritual walk?
options: Trusting God to bless us when we honor Him sincerely
Relying on our own efforts without faith
Expecting blessings without obedience
Doubting God’s provision
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God to bless us when we honor Him sincerely
questions.explanation: Judges 17:13 shows Micah’s confidence that the Lord will do good because he has a Levite as a priest, emphasizing trust in God’s goodness when we honor Him.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 17:1 introduces Micah as a man from Mount Ephraim who exemplifies faithfulness to God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 17:1 simply identifies Micah’s location but the chapter later reveals his flawed actions, so calling him an example of faithfulness is incorrect.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 17:6 shows that without godly leadership, people tend to follow their own desires rather than God’s commands.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 states there was no king in Israel and everyone did what was right in their own eyes, illustrating the need for godly leadership.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Judges 17:10 teaches us that supporting those who serve in ministry includes providing __________, clothing, and food.
options: ten shekels of silver
a church building
a vehicle
land
questions.correctAnswer: ten shekels of silver
questions.explanation: Judges 17:10 mentions Micah offering the Levite ten shekels of silver per year, a suit of apparel, and victuals, showing practical support for ministry workers.

questions.question: How does Micah’s actions in Judges 17:2-4 illustrate the importance of repentance and restitution in Christian living?
options: He confesses taking silver and returns it, showing repentance and making restitution
He hides his theft and keeps the silver
He denies the accusations to avoid consequences
He argues that the silver was rightfully his
questions.correctAnswer: He confesses taking silver and returns it, showing repentance and making restitution
questions.explanation: Judges 17:2-4 shows Micah admitting to taking his mother’s silver and returning it, demonstrating the biblical principle of repentance and restitution.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from the Levite’s acceptance of Micah’s offer in Judges 17:11?
options: The Levite was content to serve where God placed him, reflecting humility
The Levite demanded more than was offered
The Levite rejected the offer to serve elsewhere
The Levite sought power over others
questions.correctAnswer: The Levite was content to serve where God placed him, reflecting humility
questions.explanation: Judges 17:11 highlights the Levite’s contentment and acceptance of Micah’s offer, teaching humility and trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: How can Judges 17:5-6 serve as a warning against forming private religious practices apart from God’s Word?
options: Micah made his own gods and priest, showing danger of improper worship
It is acceptable to create personal gods for worship
Private religious practices are always approved by God
God blesses all forms of worship regardless of form
questions.correctAnswer: Micah made his own gods and priest, showing danger of improper worship
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5-6 reveals Micah’s idolatry and self-appointed priesthood, warning about the consequences of deviating from God’s prescribed worship.

questions.question: What does Judges 17 teach about the importance of family involvement in spiritual life, especially in parenting and discipleship?
options: Micah consecrated his son as priest, showing family’s role in spiritual leadership
Family has no role in spiritual matters
Spiritual leadership should be left to strangers
Parents should avoid involving children in religious duties
questions.correctAnswer: Micah consecrated his son as priest, showing family’s role in spiritual leadership
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 describes Micah consecrating his son as priest, indicating the significance of family participation in spiritual life, albeit incorrectly in this case.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 17.

questions.question: What is the name of the man from Mount Ephraim introduced in Judges 17?
options: Micah
Gideon
Ehud
Barak
questions.correctAnswer: Micah
questions.explanation: The chapter begins by introducing a man named Micah from Mount Ephraim (Judges 17:1).

questions.question: How much silver did Micah admit to taking from his mother?
options: 1100 shekels
200 shekels
500 shekels
1500 shekels
questions.correctAnswer: 1100 shekels
questions.explanation: Micah confessed to taking eleven hundred shekels of silver from his mother (Judges 17:2).

questions.question: What did Micah's mother dedicate the silver for?
options: To make a graven image and molten image
To build a temple
To pay off debts
To buy land
questions.correctAnswer: To make a graven image and molten image
questions.explanation: She had dedicated the silver to the LORD to make a graven image and molten image (Judges 17:3).

questions.question: How many shekels of silver did Micah's mother give to the founder for making the images?
options: 200 shekels
1100 shekels
100 shekels
500 shekels
questions.correctAnswer: 200 shekels
questions.explanation: She took 200 shekels and gave them to the founder to make the images (Judges 17:4).

questions.question: What items did Micah have in his house that were associated with worship?
options: An ephod and teraphim
A golden calf and incense altar
A menorah and tabernacle
A scroll and ark
questions.correctAnswer: An ephod and teraphim
questions.explanation: Micah had an ephod and teraphim in his house (Judges 17:5).

questions.question: What was the spiritual role assigned to one of Micah's sons?
options: He was consecrated as a priest
He became a prophet
He was made a judge
He was sent as a Levite to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He was consecrated as a priest
questions.explanation: Micah consecrated one of his sons who became his priest (Judges 17:5).

questions.question: What does Judges 17:6 say about leadership and morality in Israel at that time?
options: There was no king in Israel, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
A king ruled Israel and established strict laws
The priests controlled all religious matters
The people followed the judges strictly
questions.correctAnswer: There was no king in Israel, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states there was no king and everyone did what was right in their own eyes (Judges 17:6).

questions.question: From which city and tribe did the Levite mentioned in the chapter come?
options: Bethlehemjudah, Tribe of Judah
Shiloh, Tribe of Ephraim
Hebron, Tribe of Judah
Bethel, Tribe of Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Bethlehemjudah, Tribe of Judah
questions.explanation: The Levite was from Bethlehemjudah of the family of Judah (Judges 17:7).

questions.question: What motivated the Levite to leave Bethlehemjudah and go to Mount Ephraim?
options: To sojourn where he could find a place
To become a judge in Ephraim
To escape persecution
To fight in a tribal war
questions.correctAnswer: To sojourn where he could find a place
questions.explanation: The Levite was seeking a place to sojourn and thus traveled to Mount Ephraim (Judges 17:8).

questions.question: What did Micah offer the Levite in return for becoming his priest?
options: Ten shekels of silver per year, a suit of apparel, and victuals
Land and a house
A share of the silver from the images
A position as a judge
questions.correctAnswer: Ten shekels of silver per year, a suit of apparel, and victuals
questions.explanation: Micah promised the Levite ten shekels of silver yearly, a suit of apparel, and food (Judges 17:10).

questions.question: True or False: The Levite was unwilling to live with Micah and declined the offer to be his priest.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The Levite was content to dwell with Micah and became like one of his sons (Judges 17:11).

questions.question: What action did Micah take to install the Levite as his priest?
options: He consecrated the Levite
He sent him to the tabernacle
He anointed him with oil
He made a covenant with him
questions.correctAnswer: He consecrated the Levite
questions.explanation: Micah consecrated the Levite who then served as priest in his house (Judges 17:12).

questions.question: What was Micah's reason for believing the LORD would do good to him after obtaining a Levite as priest?
options: Having a Levite to serve as priest would bring him favor
Because he built a temple
Because he gave a large offering
Because he destroyed the graven image
questions.correctAnswer: Having a Levite to serve as priest would bring him favor
questions.explanation: Micah said he now knew the LORD would do him good because he had a Levite to be his priest (Judges 17:13).

questions.question: The presence of an ephod and teraphim in Micah's house signifies what about the religious practices in this chapter's context?
options: Syncretistic worship blending official cultic items with idolatry
Strict worship of Yahweh alone
Exclusive reliance on the tabernacle priesthood
The prophetic office was well established
questions.correctAnswer: Syncretistic worship blending official cultic items with idolatry
questions.explanation: The ephod was a priestly garment, while teraphim were household idols, showing a mixture of worship styles (Judges 17:5).

questions.question: The statement 'In those days there was no king in Israel' (Judges 17:6) foreshadows which significant event in Israel's history?
options: The anointing of Saul as the first king
The building of Solomon's temple
The Exodus from Egypt
The Babylonian exile
questions.correctAnswer: The anointing of Saul as the first king
questions.explanation: The lack of a king and moral relativism in Judges sets the stage for Israel's demand for a king, leading to Saul's anointing (1 Samuel 8-10).

theological.title: Judges Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Judges 17 reveal about the spiritual state of Israel during the time of Micah?
options: There was no king in Israel, and everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
Israel was united under a righteous king who led them in true worship.
The Levites were faithfully serving in the temple in Jerusalem.
God had established a clear prophetic leadership over Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: There was no king in Israel, and everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 states that there was no king in Israel and that every man did what was right in his own eyes, revealing a period of spiritual anarchy and moral relativism. This is consistent with biblical themes of the need for godly leadership (1 Samuel 8:7; Proverbs 29:2; Romans 13:1-4; 2 Chronicles 19:4-7).

questions.question: What theological error is demonstrated by Micah's creation of a graven image and molten image?
options: Idolatry, violating the commandment against making images.
Faithful worship according to God's law.
Proper use of silver as a temple offering.
Exclusive worship of Yahweh without images.
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry, violating the commandment against making images.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:3-4 shows that Micah’s mother dedicated silver to make graven and molten images, which is idolatry forbidden in Exodus 20:4-5 and Deuteronomy 5:8-9. This reflects humanity's sinful tendency to create false gods (Psalm 115:4-8; Isaiah 44:9-20; 1 Corinthians 10:14; 1 John 5:21).

questions.question: How does the Levite's acceptance of Micah's offer illustrate the problem of improper priesthood in Israel?
options: A Levite served as a priest outside the divinely appointed Levitical system.
The Levite was properly ordained according to Mosaic law.
God commanded the Levite to serve Micah's household.
The Levite refused to serve Micah, maintaining purity.
questions.correctAnswer: A Levite served as a priest outside the divinely appointed Levitical system.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:10-12 shows Micah consecrating a Levite to be his priest, which is unauthorized because priestly service was to be limited to the descendants of Aaron and in the tabernacle/temple (Exodus 28:1; Leviticus 8; Hebrews 7:11-14). This reflects the corruption and confusion of religious offices (1 Samuel 2:12-17; Jeremiah 23:1-2; Ezekiel 34:1-10; Malachi 2:7-9).

questions.question: What does Micah’s confidence that the LORD will do him good because he has a Levite priest reveal about his understanding of God?
options: He mistakenly equates having a priest with guaranteed divine blessing.
He fully understands God's grace and mercy.
He recognizes the need for repentance and faith.
He trusts God’s sovereign will apart from religious acts.
questions.correctAnswer: He mistakenly equates having a priest with guaranteed divine blessing.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:13 reveals Micah’s belief that having a Levite priest will ensure God's favor, showing a misunderstanding of true worship and salvation by grace, similar to Israel’s later reliance on external rituals rather than heart obedience (Isaiah 29:13; Amos 5:21-24; Hosea 6:6; Hebrews 9:11-14; Romans 3:28).

questions.question: What does the story of Micah and the Levite teach about human attempts to control and domesticate the divine?
options: Humans often try to create gods and priests for personal benefit.
God is always pleased with human religious innovation.
Divine worship always follows human traditions perfectly.
God accepts any form of worship as long as it is sincere.
questions.correctAnswer: Humans often try to create gods and priests for personal benefit.
questions.explanation: Judges 17 shows Micah making images and appointing his own priest, highlighting humanity’s tendency to shape religion to suit personal convenience rather than submitting to God's revealed will (Isaiah 44:9-20; Jeremiah 10:1-16; Romans 1:21-23; Colossians 2:8; Revelation 22:18-19).

questions.question: How does the absence of a king in Israel contribute to the religious chaos depicted in this chapter?
options: Without centralized leadership, people follow their own desires in worship.
It led to a stronger adherence to Mosaic Law.
The priests maintained perfect order in religious matters.
The prophets corrected all errors promptly.
questions.correctAnswer: Without centralized leadership, people follow their own desires in worship.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:6 states the lack of a king resulted in everyone doing what was right in their own eyes, causing religious disorder. This aligns with biblical emphasis on godly rulers to maintain justice and true worship (1 Samuel 8:6-7; Proverbs 29:2; Ecclesiastes 8:4; Romans 13:1-7; 1 Timothy 2:1-2).

questions.question: What does the term 'teraphim' in Judges 17:5 suggest about the type of idolatry present in Micah's household?
options: Use of household idols or ancestral images.
Exclusive worship of the LORD without images.
Proper use of the Ark of the Covenant.
Worship involving only the tabernacle rituals.
questions.correctAnswer: Use of household idols or ancestral images.
questions.explanation: The teraphim mentioned in Judges 17:5 were small household idols or divination objects condemned in Scripture (Genesis 31:19,34; 1 Samuel 15:23; Ezekiel 21:21; Zechariah 10:2). Their presence indicates syncretistic idolatry conflicting with pure worship of God (Exodus 20:4-5; Deuteronomy 18:10-12; 1 Corinthians 10:20).

questions.question: Why is Micah’s act of restoring the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother significant in the narrative?
options: It shows a complex mixture of repentance and continued idolatry.
It demonstrates complete obedience to God’s commands.
It reflects total rejection of idolatry in the family.
It indicates that the silver was never stolen.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows a complex mixture of repentance and continued idolatry.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:2-4 describes Micah returning the stolen silver, which his mother had dedicated for idolatrous images. Though the silver’s return suggests repentance, the continued making of idols reveals ongoing sin, illustrating human inconsistency in faith (Exodus 32:1-35; Judges 2:11-19; Jeremiah 3:22; Romans 7:15-25; James 1:14-15).

questions.question: What does the Levite’s willingness to serve Micah for pay suggest about the priesthood at this time?
options: The priesthood was corrupted by mercenary motives.
The Levite served voluntarily out of true devotion.
All Levites were properly ordained by God’s law.
The temple priests rejected him due to sin.
questions.correctAnswer: The priesthood was corrupted by mercenary motives.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:10 notes Micah offered the Levite ten shekels, clothing, and food to be his priest, indicating a mercenary approach to sacred office. This reflects a corrupted priesthood motivated by gain, warned against in Scriptures (1 Samuel 2:12-17; Ezekiel 22:26; Malachi 1:6-14; Matthew 23:27-28; 2 Peter 2:1-3).

questions.question: How does the story of Micah's house of gods reflect on the biblical doctrine of true worship?
options: It exemplifies worship that is idolatrous and unauthorized by God.
It shows that God accepts all types of worship.
It confirms that personal images are acceptable in worship.
It demonstrates proper adherence to the Mosaic covenant.
questions.correctAnswer: It exemplifies worship that is idolatrous and unauthorized by God.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 describes Micah having a house of gods with graven images and unauthorized priests, contrasting with biblical teaching that true worship is directed to the invisible God, forbidding idols (Deuteronomy 12:29-32; Isaiah 42:8; John 4:23-24; 1 Corinthians 10:14; Hebrews 9:1-14).

questions.question: What does the journey of the Levite from Bethlehemjudah to Mount Ephraim symbolize in the biblical narrative?
options: The spiritual wandering and instability of religious leadership during the period.
A divinely ordained mission to reform the house of Micah.
A return to Jerusalem to serve in the temple.
An exile due to unfaithfulness to God.
questions.correctAnswer: The spiritual wandering and instability of religious leadership during the period.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:7-8 describes a Levite wandering and seeking a place to sojourn, symbolizing religious instability and lack of proper priestly order in Israel’s dark period (1 Samuel 2:12-17; Jeremiah 23:1-4; Ezekiel 34:1-10; Hosea 9:7-9; Hebrews 7:11-14).

questions.question: How does Micah’s consecration of his son as priest in Judges 17:5 conflict with God’s covenantal requirements?
options: Only descendants of Aaron were to serve as priests, not any son.
All sons were allowed to be priests regardless of tribe.
Priests were appointed by the king only.
Priesthood was open to any Israelite family.
questions.correctAnswer: Only descendants of Aaron were to serve as priests, not any son.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 notes Micah consecrated his son as priest, contrary to God's law reserving priesthood for Aaron’s descendants (Exodus 28:1; Leviticus 8; Numbers 3:10; Hebrews 7:11-14; Malachi 2:4-7). This reflects unlawful priestly claims and corruption in worship.

questions.question: What doctrinal lesson about sin and human nature can be drawn from the narrative of Micah and the Levite?
options: Human sinfulness leads to idolatry and self-directed worship without God’s guidance.
Humans naturally worship God in spirit and truth.
Sin is absent when people serve priests and have religious images.
Human nature is inherently holy and obedient.
questions.correctAnswer: Human sinfulness leads to idolatry and self-directed worship without God’s guidance.
questions.explanation: The story in Judges 17 shows that without divine rule and obedience to God’s word, human sinfulness results in idolatry and self-worship (Judges 17:6; Romans 3:23; Jeremiah 17:9; Psalm 14:1-3; 1 John 1:8).

questions.question: In what way does Judges 17 prefigure the need for Christ as the ultimate high priest?
options: It reveals the failure of human priests to mediate true worship.
The Levite perfectly fulfilled all priestly duties.
Micah’s household was the center of God’s worship.
The chapter shows the temple priesthood in full order.
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals the failure of human priests to mediate true worship.
questions.explanation: The unauthorized Levite priest in Judges 17 illustrates the inadequacy of human mediators, pointing forward to Christ’s perfect high priesthood who alone mediates salvation (Hebrews 4:14-16; Hebrews 7:23-28; Hebrews 10:11-14; Romans 8:34; 1 Timothy 2:5).

questions.question: How does the presence of the ephod in Micah’s house (Judges 17:5) inform us about the misuse of sacred objects?
options: Sacred objects were used improperly outside their God-ordained context.
The ephod was used only in the temple at Jerusalem.
The ephod was a common household decoration.
Micah’s ephod was ordained by the high priest.
questions.correctAnswer: Sacred objects were used improperly outside their God-ordained context.
questions.explanation: Judges 17:5 mentions an ephod made by Micah, which was a priestly garment used for divination and worship authorized only for the tabernacle priests (Exodus 28:6-30; Leviticus 8; 1 Samuel 2:28; Hosea 3:4). Its use in Micah’s private house shows improper use of holy items, violating God’s covenant (Deuteronomy 12:5-14; 1 Samuel 21:9-15; Jeremiah 7:9).

questions.question: What does Micah’s story teach about the consequences of rejecting God’s appointed means of worship and leadership?
options: It leads to religious confusion and moral relativism.
It results in immediate divine blessing.
It guarantees peace and unity among the tribes.
It is approved by God as a new covenant.
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to religious confusion and moral relativism.
questions.explanation: Judges 17 shows that when God’s appointed system is rejected, people create their own false worship and leadership, resulting in chaos and sin (Judges 17:6; 1 Samuel 8:11-18; Proverbs 14:12; Isaiah 1:11-17; Romans 1:21-25).
